stem: The nurse is caring for a patient receiving magnesium sulfate for preeclampsia. Based on the EHR, which actions are most appropriate, what is the likely condition, and which parameters require the closest monitoring?

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 1400: Patient Jane Doe, 28 years old, G1P0, admitted at 34 weeks gestation for preeclampsia. Currently receiving magnesium sulfate at 2 grams/hour. 1415: Noted patient is increasingly somnolent, difficult to arouse. Respiratory rate decreased from 16 to 10 breaths/min. Deep tendon reflexes are diminished (+1). 1420: Patient reports feeling flushed and warm. 1430: Urine output over the last hour was 20 mL. Fetal heart rate monitoring shows a baseline of 140 bpm with moderate variability. 1445: Called MD, awaiting orders. Will continue close monitoring of vital signs and neurological status. Patient education regarding potential medication side effects provided prior to current decline in status. Family at bedside is anxious about the patient's condition. Will continue to update them on any changes. Magnesium sulfate infusion per protocol.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: General: Patient somnolent, difficult to arouse. Skin: Flushed, warm to touch. Neuro: Deep tendon reflexes +1 bilaterally. Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. Cardiac: Regular rate and rhythm. Abdomen: Soft, non-tender. Fetal heart tones present.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
• Monitor vital signs every 15 minutes.
  • Assess deep tendon reflexes hourly.
  • Strict I&O.
  • Continuous fetal heart rate monitoring.
  • Administer magnesium sulfate 2 grams/hour.

actions.text: Increase the magnesium sulfate infusion rate.
Administer a bolus of intravenous fluids.
Document findings and continue to monitor.

rationale.correct: The patient is exhibiting signs and symptoms of magnesium toxicity, including decreased respiratory rate, diminished deep tendon reflexes, and somnolence. Discontinuing the magnesium sulfate infusion is the priority to prevent further toxicity. Calcium gluconate is the antidote for magnesium toxicity and should be readily available. Monitoring respiratory rate and deep tendon reflexes are essential to assess the severity of the toxicity and the patient's response to treatment.
rationale.incorrect: Increasing the magnesium sulfate infusion rate would exacerbate the toxicity. Administering a bolus of intravenous fluids is not indicated for magnesium toxicity and may worsen pulmonary edema if present. While documentation and monitoring are important, they are not the priority in this situation. Blood pressure, fetal heart rate and urine output are important, but not the MOST important parameters to monitor.

clinicalPearls: Magnesium toxicity can manifest as decreased respiratory rate, diminished deep tendon reflexes, and altered mental status.
Calcium gluconate is the antidote for magnesium toxicity and should be readily available when administering magnesium sulfate.
Close monitoring of respiratory rate and deep tendon reflexes is crucial when administering magnesium sulfate.

questionTrap.trap: The question trap is focusing on routine preeclampsia management rather than recognizing the signs of magnesium toxicity.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully assess the patient's current condition and lab values, and prioritize interventions based on the signs and symptoms of magnesium toxicity.

mnemonic.title: Magnesium Toxicity Symptoms
mnemonic.expansion: Muscular weakness, Absent reflexes, Generalized flushing, Tremors (may be absent), Oppression of breathing, Xerostomia (dry mouth), Impaired cardiac conduction, CNS depression, Increased drowsiness, Tightness in chest, Yawning
